prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my girlfriend she doesn’t need to make plans every time I want to game?
My girlfriend and I have been living together for 4 months now. We’ve been together for 3 years, and I’ve loved every minute of it and we absolutely adore each other.

When we first got together I gave up a lot of my free time for dates and other couple things like that. 

We would spend the night together sometimes. But when we would go home alone, to our respective houses. I would use that time to get my game time in.

Now flash forward, we live together and are obviously spending more time together. 

It all started a few weeks ago after work, when my buddy messaged me and asked me to get on and play Apex Legends, I say yeah, and tell my girlfriend I’m gonna play some games if she doesn’t mind. Up until that point we only used my Xbox as an entertainment system ( think Hulu, YouTube and Netflix.) 

I had previously taken a pretty long break from games and I didn’t expect this to be her reaction.

She said, it’s not fair for me to play games because she has nothing else to do while we play. I said, well you can watch me play jokingly, I thought she was kidding at first, but then she continued and said if I wanna make plans then to let her know so she can be busy while I’m busy. She also said she missed me. I told her we could have time for just us when I was done playing, and that it wasn’t a “plan.” I’m not going anywhere, I’ll be right here. I even told her we could talk while I played. But she didn’t want to have any of it. She just went to her sisters house for a few hours, and I proceeded to get some dubs.

Then, it became an argument we had 2-3 times. I even gave her advanced notice on an occasion or two but If she failed to make her plan she blamed it on me. So I told her ‘she didn’t need to go out every time, I’m busy. Just relax and chill on your phone or use my laptop.’ 

She’s the kinda girl who wants constant attention and I am fine with that, but I also want to chill with my friends online and play. 

AITA?

Tl;dr Girlfriend wants me to preplan my gaming time so she can make plans to go out. I said she doesn’t need to go out just because I wanna play games.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author and his girlfriend live together. The author wants to play video games, especially with friends online, but his girlfriend is upset because she feels like she has to make plans every time he wants to game. She wants to be included or have her own plans when he's gaming, otherwise she feels left out. The author argues that she doesn't need to make plans just because he's playing and that she can just relax.

First, I need to consider both perspectives. The author's main point is that he's been giving up his free time for dates and now wants to play games with friends. He's telling the girlfriend she doesn't have to make plans, but she's upset because she feels neglected. She might be feeling that when they live together, his gaming time is a way to avoid spending quality time with her. 

On the other hand, the author is trying to balance his need for personal time with her need for attention. The girlfriend's reaction might stem from insecurity or feeling that her needs aren't being met. She wants to be involved in his activities or have her own things to do, but maybe she expects more from him. 

The key points here are communication and mutual understanding. The author might not be in the wrong if he's clearly stating his needs and she's not respecting them. However, if he's not considering her feelings and not finding a middle ground, he might share some responsibility. 

The author mentions that he told her she didn't need to go out, just relax. But if she's feeling that she needs to have her own plans to not feel lonely, then maybe he's not acknowledging her need for space or activities. However, he's also within his rights to want his own time. The problem seems to be that their expectations aren't aligned. 

Maybe the author is being a little dismissive when he says she doesn't need to plan, not recognizing that she might have different needs. But it's also possible that she's overreacting and expecting him to plan for her. Without more context, like if there's a history of neglect or if she's making excessive demands, it's hard to say. 

In relationships, compromise is key. If the author is being clear about his needs but isn't considering hers, maybe he's part of the problem. On the flip side, she might need to communicate better why she feels that way. The answer might depend on whether the author is being reasonable in his stance or not. Since he's trying to have his own time and she's trying to have hers, maybe he's not in the wrong, but there's room for both to adjust. 

I think the answer here is B (No), because the author is asserting his right to have personal time and is not making her do things she doesn't want to. However, the situation could benefit from better communication and understanding from both sides.
